Question: Soon after Hermias' death, this person was invited by Philip II of Macedon to become the tutor to his son Alexander in 343 BC.
Hints: This person marked two modes of causation: proper (prior) causation and accidental (chance) causation.
The manuscripts were left from this person to his successor Theophrastus, who in turn willed them to Neleus of Scepsis.
This person "says that 'on the subject of reasoning' he 'had nothing else on an earlier date to speak of'".
